contextId.occurrenceNote: Here evil is spoken of as if it were a place that a person could avoid going to, instead of the doing of evil actions. Alternate translation: "refused to do evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: turned from evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as a barrier such as a wall or a hedge surrounds and protects one's land, God has surrounded Job with his protection. Alternate translation: "protected him and his house and all that is his" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: put a barrier around him, around his house, and around all that is his from every side

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fell" represents the idea of attacking. Alternate translation: "attacked them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: fell on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "edge" represents the part of swords that kill people, that is, either the point or the sharp edge. Also, all the swords of the Sabeans are spoken of as if they were only one sword. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])
contextId.glQuote: the edge of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "edge" represents the part of swords that kill people, that is, either the point or the sharp edge. Also, all the swords of the Chaldeans are spoken of as if they were only one sword. See how you translated this in [Job 1:15](../01/15.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])
contextId.glQuote: As for the servants, they have struck them with the edge of the sword. I alone have escaped to tell you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a time when God is paying attention. Alternate translation: "in your hearing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to your face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a wish for that day to not exist any longer. Alternate translation: "may that day disappear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: May that day be dark

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a shadow represents death itself. Alternate translation: "death like a shadow" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the shadow of death

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a cloud is spoken of as if it were a person who could live over the day of Job's birth. Alternate translation: "May a cloud cover it so no one can see it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: May a cloud live over it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to things that block out the sun's light and create darkness. Here "black" represents darkness. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: everything that makes the day black

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here that the night of Job's birth is spoken of as if it were a time when it was still possible for someone to be happy. Alternate translation: "may no one hear the happy cry at the birth of a son" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: may no joyful voice come into it

contextId.occurrenceNote: A woman's womb is spoken of as if it were a container with doors. Alternate translation: "because that day did not close my mother's womb" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: because it did not shut up the doors of my mother's womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here light represents life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: light

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here death is spoken of as if it were an object coming toward someone. Alternate translation: "to a person who no longer wants to be alive, but is still alive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to one who longs for death without it coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person hoping to die is spoken of as if he were digging for buried treasure. Alternate translation: "to a person who wants to stop living more than he wants to look for hidden riches" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to one who digs for death more than for hidden treasure

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here light represents life. Alternate translation: "Why does God keep a man alive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Why is light given to a man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Job speaks of his future, which he does not know in advance, as if God had hidden it from him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: whose way is hidden

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being in difficulties and dangers is spoken of as if it were being confined within narrow limits. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a man whom God has hedged in

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moral qualities and emotions such as grief are often spoken of as if they were water. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my groaning is poured out like water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Someone who has been encouraged is spoken of as if he were kept from falling down. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: supported

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here becoming discouraged is spoken of as if it were falling down. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: falling

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here discouragement is spoken of as if it were a person whose weak knees could not keep him upright. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you have made feeble knees firm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here trouble is spoken of as if it were an object that could come to a person. Alternate translation: "But now you suffer from disasters" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: But now trouble has come to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "your ways" represents "your conduct," "how you behave." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being cut off represents being destroyed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the actions of plowing and sowing represent causing trouble for other people. The action of reaping represents suffering the trouble that one has himself caused. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: plow iniquity ... sow trouble ... reap

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may represent the action of God giving a command. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the breath of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression suggests the heavy breathing that a person sometimes does through his nose when he is very angry. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the blast of his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: The second builds on the first. They make the same point by using meanings that increase the result. "By the puff of God's mouth they die; the rushing wind of his anger devastates them." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: breath ... blast

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being consumed or eaten represents being killed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they are consumed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a lion's roar, his voice, and his teeth being broken are used as pictures of the wicked being destroyed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The roaring of the lion, the voice of the fierce lion, the teeth of the young lions—they are broken.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here fear and trembling are spoken of as if they were objects that could come to a person. Alternate translation: "I began to be afraid and to tremble" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: fear and trembling came upon me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a figurative way of describing human beings, who were created out of the dust of the earth and whose bodies are like houses, which are made of clay and have dirt foundations. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: those who live in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings for this metaphor are 1) "who God destroys as easily as he crushes a moth" or 2) "whose lives are as short as the life of a moth." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: who are crushed sooner than a moth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the idea of something happening quickly. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Between morning and evening they are destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person is spoken of as if he were a plant, perhaps becoming more foolish over time. Alternate translation: "a foolish person becoming grounded in foolishness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a foolish person taking root

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being crushed represents being oppressed, taken advantage of, at court. This idea may be put into active form. Alternate translation: "someone crushes them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: are crushed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here greedy people are spoken of as if they were thirsty, and the wealth of the foolish person is spoken of as if it were something that they could drink. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The thirsty pant for their wealth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here difficulties and trouble are spoken of as if they were plants. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For difficulties do not come out from the soil; neither does trouble sprout from the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to things that mankind cannot understand. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: unsearchable things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Humble people in distress are spoken of as if they were in a low position. When God rescues them, they receive honor. When this happens, they are spoken of as being raised up and put into a high position. Alternate translation: "God does this in order to rescue and honor the humble who have been suffering" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He does this in order to set up on high those who are low

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here stopping the plans of crafty people is spoken of as if they were things that could be physically broken. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He breaks the plans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here making wise people suffer for their own evil actions is spoken of as if it were catching them in traps. Their own actions are spoken of as if they were those traps. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He traps wise people in their own crafty actions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being evil in a clever way is spoken of as if it were being twisted. Alternate translation: "those who are cunning" or "those who are devious" or "those who are shrewd" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: twisted people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the cunning, wicked people whom God confuses are spoken of as if they unexpectedly are in the dark at noon, when the sun is at its highest position in the sky. They cannot do anything they wish to do, because they cannot see. Alternate translation: "Those who are cunning are in the dark, even at noontime" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They encounter darkness in the daytime

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the insulting and threatening things that people say are spoken of as if they were a sword in their mouths. Alternate translation: "But he saves the poor person from the threats of the mighty" or "But he saves the poor person when the mighty threaten or insult them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: But he saves the poor person from the sword in their mouths

contextId.occurrenceNote: The use of increasing numbers such as "six" and "seven" represents the idea of many, many times. Alternate translation: "He will rescue you out of trouble over and over again; indeed, time after time, no evil will touch you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He will rescue you out of six troubles; indeed, in seven troubles, no evil will touch you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here rescuing is spoken of as if it were ransoming, buying back. Alternate translation: "In famine God will rescue you from danger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: In famine he will ransom you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to wild animals. Alternate translation: "wild animals" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: beasts of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the stones in farmers' fields are spoken of as if they were people that someone could have a covenant with. Alternate translation: "the stones in your fields will be like people who promise that they will not make any trouble for you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will have a covenant with the stones in your field

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "tent" represents a person's family, household, and all his possessions. Alternate translation: "You will know that your family, servants, and everything you own are safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You will know that your tent is in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "seed" represents a person's descendants. Alternate translation: "your descendants will be many" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your seed will be great

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor for Job's suffering. He compares his many troubles to arrows that that God has shot his body with. Alternate translation: "It is as though the Almighty has shot arrows into my body" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For the arrows of the Almighty are in me

contextId.occurrenceNote: "my spirit drinks up the arrows' poison." This continues the metaphor of the arrows, by implying that they had tips of poison and that Job feels the pain in his spirit. He speaks of feeling this pain as if his spirit drank the poison. Alternate translation: "I feel the pain of their poison in my inner being" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my spirit drinks up the poison

contextId.occurrenceNote: God causing many things to terrify Job is spoken of as if God's terrors were soldiers lined up to attack Job. Alternate translation: "the terrors of God have arranged themselves like soldiers in an army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the terrors of God have arranged themselves in array against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Job is comparing his displeasure for his circumstances to people's dislike for bland food or 2) Job is comparing his displeasure for his friend's advice to people's dislike for bland food. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Can that which has no taste be eaten without salt? Or is there any taste in the white of an egg?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a person who feels hopeless and is overwhelmed by his troubles as if he were about to physically faint. Alternate translation: "who feels hopeless" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who is about to faint

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job is continuing his description of his friends being as unreliable as streams that dry up. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The worms and clods of dust are pictured as covering Job as if they were clothing. Alternate translation: "My flesh is covered with worms and clods of dust" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares the shortness of his life to the shortness of a breath. Alternate translation: "my life is very short, like taking one breath" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my life is only a breath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sorrow is spoken of as if it tasted bitter, and "soul" refers to the whole man. Alternate translation: "with anger and resentment" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: in the bitterness of my soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bildad speaks of Job's words as if they are as empty and insubstantial as the wind. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "The words of your mouth are as insignificant as a mighty wind." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How long will the words of your mouth be a mighty wind?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is spoken of as if he woke from sleep to help Job. Alternate translation: "help you" or "do good things for you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: stir himself on your behalf

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here lack of wealth is spoken of as being a "small beginning." Alternate translation: "Even if you were poor early in your life, God would make you very wealthy later in your life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Even though your beginning was small, still your final condition would be much greater

contextId.occurrenceNote: The shortness of life is spoken of as if it were a shadow which quickly disappears. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: our days on earth are a shadow

contextId.occurrenceNote: This statement probably refers to a man relying on his property and wealth for security. If so, then "house" here represents the owner's property and wealth. Alternate translation: "He thinks he will be safe because he is wealthy, but he will not be safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He leans on his house, but it will not support him; he takes hold of it, but it does not stand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Bildad compares the godless person to a plant that is healthy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Under the sun he is green, and his shoots go out over his entire garden

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bildad continues the metaphor from [Job 8:16-18](./16.md). Other godless people are spoken of as plants who take the place of the first godless man when he dies. Alternate translation: "when one wicked man dies, another will take his place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: other plants will sprout out of the same soil in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: God causing Job to laugh is spoken of as if God had poured laughter into Job's mouth. Alternate translation: "cause you to continually laugh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: fill your mouth with laughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "shame" is spoken of as if it were clothing that God will cause Job's enemies to wear. This means they will be very ashamed. Alternate translation: "God will cause those who hate you to be very ashamed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Those who hate you will be clothed with shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is spoken of as calming the sea as if with his feet. Alternate translation: "puts his feet down on the waves of the sea" or "calms the waves of the sea" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: tramples down the waves of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares his troubles from God to the effects of a tempest. Alternate translation: "He injures me as if with a tempest" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For he breaks me with a tempest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This verse pictures God as filling up Job's life with things that make him bitter. The abstract noun "bitterness" can be expressed as the adjective "bitter." Alternate translation: "he fills me up with bitter things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: he fills me with bitterness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my words" are spoken of as if they could take action. Alternate translation: "God would use what I say to prove me guilty" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my words would prove me to be guilty

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "whip" here is a metaphor for any kind of disaster. Alternate translation: "When a disaster suddenly happens and people die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When a whip suddenly kills

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's sad face is spoken of here as if it was something that could be removed. Alternate translation: "I would stop looking unhappy and smile" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I would take off my sad face and be happy

contextId.occurrenceNote: How Job feels is compared to a bitter taste. The abstract noun "bitterness" can be translated as the adverb "bitterly." Alternate translation: "My inner being will speak bitterly" or "I will bitterly speak out" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: I will speak in the bitterness of my soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job is using a metaphor of a potter forming clay to describe how God carefully created him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Your hands have framed and fashioned me together round about

contextId.occurrenceNote: God putting skin and flesh on Job's body is spoken of as if God was putting clothing on him. Alternate translation: "You have put skin and flesh on my body" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You have clothed me with skin and flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: "wove me together." God putting Job's body together in the womb is spoken of as if God was knitting or weaving a piece of cloth. Alternate translation: "put me together" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: knit me together

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's troubles from God are spoken of as if they were people who were witnesses against him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You bring new witnesses against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: God sending troubles against Job is spoken of as if God was constantly sending new armies against him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you attack me with fresh armies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being brought out of the womb represents being born into this world. Alternate translation: "brought me out of my mother's womb" or "brought me into this world" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: brought me out of the womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Giving up one's spirit represents dying. Alternate translation: "died" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: given up my spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the place where the spirits of dead people go is spoken of as if it was a land. Alternate translation: "the place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent sight, which is a metaphor for God's evaluation of Job. Possible meanings are 1) that Job is saying that God judges him as blameless. Alternate translation: "You say that I am blameless" or 2) that Job believes he has been blameless and that God should judge him as blameless. Alternate translation: "You should recognize that I am blameless" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am blameless in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Demanding from Job represents punishing Job. Alternate translation: "God is punishing you less than you deserve" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God demands from you less than your iniquity deserves

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's greatness or wisdom is spoken of as if it could be measured in distance. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: is longer than the earth ... wider than the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: The heart represents thoughts and attitudes. Setting it right represents correcting it. Alternate translation: "even if you had corrected your attitude" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: suppose that you had set your heart right

contextId.occurrenceNote: Putting sin behind represents stopping sinning. Alternate translation: "but that then you stopped doing evil things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but that then you put it far away from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Brightness represents being prosperous and happy. Alternate translation: "Your life would be prosperous and happy like the noonday" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Your life would be brighter than the noonday

contextId.occurrenceNote: The morning represents light, which represents prosperity and happiness. Alternate translation: "it would be prosperous and happy like the morning" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it would become like the morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their eyes represent their understanding. Alternate translation: "the understanding of the wicked people will fail" or "the wicked people will not be able to understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the eyes of wicked people will fail

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bringing misfortune represents causing it to happen. Alternate translation: "causes more bad things to happen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: brings more misfortune

contextId.occurrenceNote: The foot slipping represents being in danger or trouble. Alternate translation: "to those who are already in trouble" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to those whose foot is slipping

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that withholding waters represents 1) preventing the rain from falling. Alternate translation: "if he stops the rain from falling the land dries up" or 2) preventing running water from flowing. Alternate translation: "if he stops the water from flowing, the land dries up" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if he withholds the waters, they dry up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that sending them out is a metaphor meaning 1) causing the rain to fall. Alternate translation: "if he causes a lot of rain to fall, it floods the land" or 2) causing the waters to flow. Alternate translation: "if he makes a lot of water flow, it floods the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if he sends them out, they overwhelm the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Leading counselors away barefoot represents taking away their wisdom and authority. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He leads counselors away barefoot

contextId.occurrenceNote: Leading priests away barefoot represents taking away their authority. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He leads priests away barefoot

contextId.occurrenceNote: Pouring contempt on princes is a metaphor for causing people to feel contempt for them. Alternate translation: "He causes people to greatly disrespect those who rule" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He pours contempt upon princes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The belt is a symbol of strength. Unfastening a strong person's belt represents taking away his strength and making him weak. Alternate translation: "makes the strong people weak" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: unfastens the belt of strong people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Revealing things represents making them known. "Deep things from darkness" represent secrets that people do not know. Alternate translation: "He makes known secrets that people do not know" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He reveals the deep things of darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bringing things out into the light represents making them known, and here "shadows" is a metonym for the things that are hidden in the shadows, which in turn are a metaphor for truths that God has hidden from people. Alternate translation: "makes known things that no one can see" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: brings deep shadows into the light

contextId.occurrenceNote: Taking away their understanding represents causing them to be unable to understand. Alternate translation: "He causes the leaders of the people of the earth to be unable to understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He takes away understanding from the leaders of the people of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wandering in a wilderness where there is no path represents being in a difficult situation and not knowing what to do. Alternate translation: "to be unsure of what to do like a person wandering in a wasteland with no path" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to wander in a wilderness where there is no path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being in the dark without light represents lacking knowledge. Alternate translation: "They struggle to make decisions without knowledge as people struggle to walk in the dark without light" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They grope in the dark without light

contextId.occurrenceNote: Putting whitewash or plaster on the truth represents ignoring the truth. Alternate translation: "you hide the truth with lies" or "you lie and ignore the truth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you whitewash the truth with lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being a physician represents being a person who comforts others. Being of no value means that they do not know how to do what they should. Alternate translation: "you are all like physicians who do not know how to heal people" or "you all come to comfort me, but you do not know how, like unskilled physicians" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you are all physicians of no value

contextId.occurrenceNote: Dread falling on people represents them becoming terribly afraid. Alternate translation: "and you not be terribly afraid" or "and you not be terrified" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: and the dread of him fall upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ashes represent things that are worthless and do not last. Alternate translation: "Your memorable sayings are worthless like ashes" or "Your memorable sayings will be forgotten like ashes that are blown away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Your memorable sayings are proverbs made of ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of what they say as if it were a wall made of clay around a city; it cannot defend the people because clay breaks easily. Alternate translation: "What you say in defense is as useless as a wall of clay" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your defenses are defenses made of clay

contextId.occurrenceNote: Things coming on a person represents things happening to a person. This expression starting with "let" means that he does not care what might happen to him. Alternate translation: "let whatever may happen to me happen" or "I do not care what may happen to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: let come what may on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Setting his defense in order represents deciding what he will say to defend himself. Alternate translation: "I have thought through how I will defend myself" or "I have decided how I will explain myself" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have set my defense in order

contextId.occurrenceNote: Giving up one's life is a metaphor for dying. Alternate translation: "die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: give up my life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiding one's face from someone represents refusing to look at him or ignoring him. Alternate translation: "you refuse to look at me" or "you ignore me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you hide your face from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Bitter things" represents accusations. Alternate translation: "For you write down accusations against me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For you write down bitter things against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Inheriting the iniquities of his youth is a metaphor. Possible meanings are it represents 1) being guilty for the sins of his youth. Alternate translation: "you say that I am still guilty for the sins of my youth" or 2) being punished for the sins of his youth. Alternate translation: "you punish me for the sins of my youth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you make me inherit the iniquities of my youth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Doing this represents punishing Job and keeping him from living freely as if Job had committed a crime and was a prisoner. Alternate translation: "It is as though you put my feet in the stocks" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You also put my feet in the stocks

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Paths" represent the things Job does. Alternate translation: "everything I do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: all my paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: Examining this ground represents examining all that Job has done. Alternate translation: "it is as though you examine the ground where I have walked" or "you examine everything I do like a person examining someone's footprints on the ground" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you examine the ground where the soles of my feet have walked

contextId.occurrenceNote: Passing a limit represents living past a time that God has set for a person to die. Alternate translation: "you have appointed the time that he will die, and he cannot live longer than that" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you have appointed his limits that he cannot pass

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disappearing represents dying. Alternate translation: "so that its young shoot will not die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: so that its tender stalk does not disappear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lying down represents dying. Alternate translation: "so people die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: so people lie down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rising again represents living again. Alternate translation: "do not live again" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: do not rise again

contextId.occurrenceNote: Keeping track of Job's sin represents thinking about his sin. Alternate translation: "you would not look at my sin" or "you would not think about my sin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you would not keep track of my sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sealing transgression in a bag represents hiding it and refusing to think about it. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "You would refuse to think about my transgression like someone who hides something in a bag" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My transgression would be sealed up in a bag

contextId.occurrenceNote: Covering up someone's iniquity so that it cannot be seen represents refusing to think about it. Alternate translation: "you would hide my iniquity" or "you would ignore my iniquity" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you would cover up my iniquity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Destroying hope represents causing the things people hope for not to happen. Alternate translation: "You prevent the hope of man from happening" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you destroy the hope of man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents causing him to die. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: send him away to die

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being brought low represents being shamed. Alternate translation: "if they are disgraced" or "if people shame them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if they are brought low

contextId.occurrenceNote: The wind represents emptiness. This phrase speaks of a person speaking empty and meaningless words as if that person were full of the wind. Alternate translation: "fill himself with empty words" or "only have meaningless words" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: fill himself with the east wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Eliphaz speaks of him and the other men having learned wisdom from older men and wisdom that had been passed down from men of previous generations as if these older men were physically present with them. Alternate translation: "We acquired wisdom from old gray-haired people, from people who were born before your father was" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: With us are both the gray-headed and the very aged men

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if the person were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something that God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if it were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "in his judgment" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in his sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes iniquity as if it were water you can drink. It compares how the evil man desires to commit sin to how readily he desires to drink cool water. Alternate translation: "who love iniquity as much as they love a cup of fresh water" or "who commit evil deeds as often as they drink water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who drinks iniquity like water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the wicked man acting aggressively against God as if he were running towards him to attack him. Alternate translation: "attacks God" or "acts violently against God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: runs at God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the flame represents God's judgment and the drying up of his stalks represents either the fact that his possessions disappear, or that he will die. Alternate translation: "God will take everything he owns away, like a fire dries out the moist branches of a tree" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a flame will dry up his stalks

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the man looking pale and dead as if he were a dried out stalk or tree branch. Alternate translation: "he will look dead, just like the branch of a dead tree does not look green" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his branch will not be green

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the wicked man growing weak and dying as if he were a grapevine dropping unripe grapes. Alternate translation: "Just like a grapevine drops its unripe grapes, so the wicked man will drop his strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He will drop his unripe grapes like a grapevine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the wicked man growing weak and dying as if he were were an olive tree dropping its flowers. Alternate translation: "just like an olive tree loses its flowers, so the wicked man will lose his strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he will cast off his flowers like the olive tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of thinking of useless things to say as if his words were random items that he collected and joined together. Alternate translation: "I could think of things to say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I could collect and join words together

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of grief as if it were a heavy physical burden. Alternate translation: "will lessen your grief" or "will help you feel less grief" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will bring you relief

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of God causing Job pain as if God were a wild animal and Job were his prey that he was killing. Alternate translation: "Because God is very angry with me, it is as though he were a wild animal that tore my body apart with his teeth because he was my enemy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God has torn me in his wrath and persecuted me ... as he tears me apart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his pain and despair as if he himself were something that was broken into pieces. Alternate translation: "but then it felt as though he broke me apart" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: and he broke me apart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God causing him pain and despair as if he were something that God had taken and smashed into pieces. Alternate translation: "it is as though he has taken me by the neck and smashed me to pieces" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: dashed me to pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of himself being the focus of God's attacks as if God has set him up as a target to shoot arrows at. Alternate translation: "it is as though he set me up like a target" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he has also set me up as his target

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of himself being the focus of God's attacks as if God has set him up as a target and God had archers surrounding him to attack him. Alternate translation: "It is as though his archers have me surrounded" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: His archers surround me all around

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the pain he is feeling by comparing it to God piercing his body with arrows. Here "God" represents the arrows that he shoots. Alternate translation: "It feels like God's arrows have pierced my kidneys and my liver, spilling my bile on the ground. He does not spare me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God pierces my kidneys and does not spare me; he pours out my bile on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the pain that he feels by comparing himself to a wall that God smashes through. Alternate translation: "I feel like a wall that God smashes through" or "I feel like a wall that God breaks through" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He smashes through my wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job describes God as a soldier that attacks him. Alternate translation: "it is like he is a warrior who runs at me to attack me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he runs upon me like a warrior

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of wearing clothing made of sackcloth as if the cloth were attached to his body. People often wore sackcloth to express mourning or great grief. Alternate translation: "Because I am mourning, I have sewn together sackcloth to wear as my clothing" or "I wear clothing that I made from sackcloth, because I am mourning" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have sewn sackcloth on my skin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's "horn" represents the power and authority he had before but now is no more. Alternate translation: "I sit here in the dirt, very depressed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have thrust my horn into the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job begins to speak to God. Here he speaks of his situation as if he were in prison. He is asking God to provide a pledge so that he may be released. Alternate translation: "God, give now a pledge so that I may be released from this prison" or "pay for my release from prison" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Give now a pledge, be a guarantee for me with yourself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a person being innocent as having clean hands. Alternate translation: "he who does what is right" or "he who is innocent" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he who has clean hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people claiming that night is day as if they actually changed night into day. Alternate translation: "claim it is daytime when it is night" or "say the opposite of what is true, just as night is the opposite of day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: change the night into day

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Job speaks of being prepared to die as having laid his bed in the darkness. Alternate translation: "have prepared myself to go and sleep among the dead" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: have spread my couch in the darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the closeness he will soon have with his grave by comparing it to the closeness a man has with his father. Alternate translation: "You are as close to me as my father" or "When I am buried, you will be as close to me as a father" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You are my father

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the closeness he will soon have with the worms in his grave by comparing it to the closeness a man has with his mother and sisters. Alternate translation: "You are as close to me as my mother or my sister" or "You will be as close to me as a mother or sister" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You are my mother or my sister

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sheol does not really have gates, but it is a metaphor for Job entering Sheol. Alternate translation: "when I go into Sheol" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: gates of Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "in your judgment" or "in your thinking" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in your sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bildad speaks of a wicked person dying as if his lamp were being blown out. Alternate translation: "What will happen is that the lives of wicked people like you end as quickly as we can put out a light or extinguish the flame of a fire" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Indeed, the light of the wicked person will be put out; the spark of his fire will not shine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bildad continues to speak of the wicked person dying. He speaks of the wicked man's life as if it were the light in his tent. Alternate translation: It will be like the light in his tent has turned to darkness, like the lamp above him has gone out" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The light will be dark in his tent; his lamp above him will be put out

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the wicked person suddenly experiencing disaster as if he no longer had strength to walk. Alternate translation: "It will be like he no longer has the strength to walk" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The steps of his strength will be made short

contextId.occurrenceNote: "his own advice makes him fall down." This speaks of the wicked person undergoing disaster as if he fell down. Alternate translation: "his own plans will lead him into disaster" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his own plans will cast him down

contextId.occurrenceNote: "His own feet will lead him into a net." Bildad uses this image to say that the way that a wicked person lives his life leads him to sudden disaster. Alternate translation: "It will be as though he led himself into a net, as if he walked right into a pitfall" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For he will be thrown into a net by his own feet; he will walk into a pitfall

contextId.occurrenceNote: These four phrases speak of the wicked man experiencing disaster as if he were caught in a trap. Alternate translation: "It will be as though a trap will take him ... a snare will" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: A trap will take him ... a snare will

contextId.occurrenceNote: These four phrases speak of the wicked man experiencing disaster as if he were caught in a trap. Alternate translation: "It will be as though a noose is ... and a trap for him in the way" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: A noose is ... and a trap for him in the way

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the wicked man becoming poor and hungry as if his wealth were something that turned into something else. Alternate translation: "Instead of being wealthy, he will become poor and hungry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: His wealth will turn into hunger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a disease that kills many people is referred to as "the firstborn of death." This speaks of that disease destroying his body as if it were an animal that had attacked him and was eating him. Alternate translation: "a deadly disease will destroy the different parts of his body" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the firstborn of death will devour his parts

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the wicked man dying and having no descendants as if he were a tree whose roots dried up and branches withered, producing no fruit. Alternate translation: "He will die and leave no descendants, he will be like a tree whose roots have dried up and whose branches have all withered" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: His roots will be dried up ... branch be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the "memory" of the wicked man as if it were a person who died. Alternate translation: "No one on the earth will remember him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: His memory will perish from the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of God making him leave earth and go where dead people go as if he were chasing him. Alternate translation: "God will make him leave this world" or "God will send him to the place where dead people go" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: be chased out of this world

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job uses this image to say that their words make him feel very sad and hopeless. Alternate translation: "torment me with your words" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: break me into pieces with words

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks as if God were a hunter that has trapped Job in his net. This metaphor represents God taking control of Job and Job's feeling of helplessness. Alternate translation: "has trapped me" or "has taken control of me" or "has control of what happens to me, so that I am helpless" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: has caught me in his net

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job uses these images to describe how God has made him feel helpless and hopeless. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He has walled up ... darkness in my path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job uses these images to say that God has taken his good reputation, wealth, and dignity away from him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He has stripped ... the crown from my head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his glory as if it were a robe that God has taken away. Alternate translation: "He has taken away my glory" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He has stripped me of my glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: The crown refers to Job's dignity or honor. Alternate translation: "he has taken away my dignity and honor" or "it is as though he has taken my crown off my head" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he has taken the crown from my head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God ruining him as if Job were building that God is smashing down. Alternate translation: "He has ruined me in every way" or "He has attacked me in every way" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He has broken me down on every side

contextId.occurrenceNote: The metaphor "being gone" represents being completely destroyed. Alternate translation: "I am completely destroyed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am gone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God's wrath as if it were a fire. Alternate translation: "God has also lit a fire of anger against me" or "God has also become very angry with me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He has also kindled his wrath against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God attacking him as if Job was a city and God was sending an army to attack it. Alternate translation: "God sends his army to attack me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: His troops come on together

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God attacking him as if Job was a city and God's army was piling up dirt against the city wall in order to climb over the wall and attack the city. Alternate translation: "the soldiers pile up dirt in order to climb over my wall" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they cast up siege mounds against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God attacking him as if Job was in his tent and God's army was camping around him and preparing to attack him. Alternate translation: "they camp around my tent and prepare to attack me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: encamp around my tent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being "far from" someone represents being unwilling to relate to him or help him. Alternate translation: "God has caused my brothers to stay away from me" or "God caused my brothers to refuse to help me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He has put my brothers far from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job describes how people now think of him as an outsider. Here sight represents judgement or evaluation. Alternate translation: "they think of me as a foreigner" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am an alien in their sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his friends speaking so cruelly to him as if they were wild beasts eating up another animal. Alternate translation: "Stop violently slandering me." or "Stop attacking me with your words." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Will you ever be satisfied with my flesh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: People thought of the heart as being where the emotions are. So the heart failing represents him having very many emotions. Alternate translation: "I am very emotional about it" or "My emotions overwhelm me as I think about that" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My heart fails within me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "root" represents the source. Alternate translation: "He is the source of all his troubles" or "He has all these troubles because of what he has done" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The root of his troubles lies in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of Zophar's thoughts making him do something represents his strong desire to do something. Alternate translation: "I want very much to answer you quickly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My thoughts make me answer quickly

contextId.occurrenceNote: The wicked man's height represents either his reputation or his pride. Also, here "reaches up to the heavens" represents being very great. Alternate translation: "Though his reputation is great" or "Though his pride is great" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Though his height reaches up to the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: "and though his head is as high as the clouds." This also represents his reputation or pride being great. This means the same as the previous phrase. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: his head reaches to the clouds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "wickedness is sweet" represents a person enjoying doing wicked things. Alternate translation: "Although doing wicked things is pleasurable like tasting sweet food in the mouth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Although wickedness is sweet in his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zophar speaks of wickedness as if it were sweet food that a person puts under his tongue so it will stay in his mouth and he can taste it for a long time. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: although he hides it under his tongue

contextId.occurrenceNote: When food turns bitter in the stomach, it causes pain and a bitter taste. This is a metaphor for a person experiencing the painful consequences of doing wicked things. Alternate translation: "those wicked things become like food that has turned bitter in the stomach" or "the consequences of those wicked things are painful like food that becomes sour in the stomach" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the food in his intestines turns bitter

contextId.occurrenceNote: This image is even worse than sour food in the stomach. This is a metaphor for a person experiencing the terrible consequences of doing wicked things. Alternate translation: "the consequences of doing those wicked things are painful like the poison of asps inside him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it becomes the poison of asps inside him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zophar speaks of gaining and losing wealth as if it were food that a person eats and vomits. Alternate translation: "The wicked person becomes very wealthy, but he loses his wealth like a person who vomits up his food. God causes him to lose it all" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He swallows down riches ... cast them out of his stomach

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that "swallows down riches" represents 1) accumulating riches and storing them selfishly. Alternate translation: "The wicked man gains much wealth and keeps it all for himself" or 2) accumulating riches in wicked ways. Alternate translation: "The wicked man steals many riches" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He swallows down riches

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "suck the poison of asps" represents doing evil things. Both are very dangerous. Alternate translation: "Doing evil things is like sucking the poison of asps" or "He will do evil things and endanger his life like a person who sucks the poison of asps" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He will suck the poison of asps

contextId.occurrenceNote: The viper represents the man's wickedness. Alternate translation: "his wickedness will kill him like a viper's bite" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the viper's tongue will kill him

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Streams" and "torrents" are metaphors that represent abundance. "Honey" and "butter" are metonyms that represent the good things that God gives people. Alternate translation: "the abundance of good things that God gives his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the streams, the torrents of honey and butter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Normally "the fruit of his labor" simply refers to the results of his labor. In this case it refers to the things the wicked man had stolen. Alternate translation: "the things he had worked to get" or "the things he had stolen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: the fruit of his labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "to eat" the fruit of his labor represents enjoying the things he had stolen. Alternate translation: "will not be able to enjoy them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will not be able to eat it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "devour" represents taking things for himself. Alternate translation: "There is nothing left that he did not take for himself" or "He took everything for himself, and there is nothing left" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: There is nothing left that he did not devour

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "fierceness of his wrath" represents God's anger and punishment. Throwing the punishment on him represents punishing him severely. Alternate translation: "God will be angry and throw down his punishment on him" or "God will be angry and punish him severely" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God will throw the fierceness of his wrath on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: "God will cause it to rain down on him." Here "rain it down on him" represents causing much punishment to happen to the man. Alternate translation: "God will punish him severely" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God will rain it down on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: He will suddenly become very afraid. Alternate translation: "he is terrified" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Terrors come over him

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Complete darkness" here is a metaphor for destruction. Alternate translation: "Destruction is reserved for his treasures" or "His treasures will be destroyed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Complete darkness is reserved for his treasures

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "devour" is a metaphor meaning destroy. Alternate translation: "a fire that is not fanned will destroy him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a fire not fanned will devour him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "consume" is a metaphor meaning destroy. Alternate translation: "the fire will destroy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it will consume

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "flow away" represents being taken away from him. Alternate translation: "his goods will be taken away from him, like goods that float away in a flood, on" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his goods will flow away on

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "portion from God" represents what God has decided should happen to someone. It is spoken of as if it were something that God would give him. Alternate translation: "This is what God has decided should happen to the wicked man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: This is the wicked man's portion from God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents what God has decided should happen to someone. It is spoken of as if it were something that God would give him as an inheritance. Alternate translation: "what God has planned to give to him" or "what God has planned should happen to him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the heritage reserved for him by God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares extinguishing the lamp to a person dying. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "that God causes them to die suddenly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: the lamp of wicked people is put out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares the life of the wicked to a lamp that is burning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the lamp of wicked people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Guilt is spoken of as something that can be stored for later use. Here "to pay" refers to punishment for sin. Alternate translation: "God keeps a record of a person's sins, then he punishes the person's children for his wicked deeds" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God lays up one's guilt for his children to pay

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the wrath of God is spoken of as if it were a drink that a person can taste, and tasting is a metonym for experiencing the drink. Job wants the wicked person to experience God's punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: let him drink of the wrath of the Almighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sorrow is spoken of as if it tasted bitter, and "soul" refers to the whole man. Alternate translation: "with anger and resentment" or "after living a sad life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: in bitterness of soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are metaphors for trouble and danger. Alternate translation: "you are always in danger ... you become afraid for no reason" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: snares are all around you ... sudden fear troubles you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each of these metaphors means troubles and dangers are all around Job because of his sin. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: There is darkness ... an abundance of waters covers you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Dying is compared to God snatching them away. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "those who died" or "those whom God took away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: those who were snatched away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Eliphaz compares Job's restoration to the rebuilding of a house that has fallen. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "he will heal you and make you prosper again" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: you will be built up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Unrighteousness is pictured as a person who is living in Job's tent who must be removed. Alternate translation: "if you and everyone in your house stops sinning" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if you put unrighteousness far away from your tents

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God will be more valuable to Job than any treasure. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the Almighty will be your treasure, precious silver to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's blessing is compared to a light on all of Job's paths. Alternate translation: "it will be like a light shining on the road in front of you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: light will shine on your paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job being innocent is spoken of as if his hands were physically clean. The phrase "who will be rescued" can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will rescue even the person who is not innocent because you do what is right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: He will rescue even the man who is not innocent; who will be rescued through the cleanness of your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's actions are spoken of as if he is walking on a path. Alternate translation: "God knows what I do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he knows the way that I take

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's obedience is spoken of as if he is walking in a path that God showed him. Alternate translation: "I have done what he told me to do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have kept to his way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings of "light" are 1) visible light or 2) spiritual light, which refers to God or living righteously. Alternate translation: "hate the daylight" or "do not want to do things openly" or "rebel against God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: rebel against the light

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines describe the same thing, and are used together to emphasize that they do not want to follow the ways of the light. Alternate translation: "they do not know how to live a moral life; they stay far away from living a righteous life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: they know not its ways, nor do they stay in its paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's destruction of the wicked man is describes as if he were cutting down a tree. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "God will destroy the wicked as if he were a tree" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: wickedness will be broken like a tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor emphasizes how ruthless the wicked man is. Alternate translation: "Just like a wild animal kills its prey, so the wicked person harms" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The wicked one devours

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bildad states that human beings are as worthless as worms. Alternate translation: "who is as worthless as a worm" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who is a worm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sheol is spoken of as if it were a person. These two phrases have the same meaning. To be "naked" or have "no covering" is to be completely exposed and not able to hide anything. Alternate translation: "It is like sheol is naked before God, for nothing in sheol, the place of destruction, is hidden from God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Sheol is naked before God; destruction itself has no covering

contextId.occurrenceNote: The northern skies represent heaven, the place where God dwells with the beings he created to dwell there. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He stretches out the northern skies over the empty space

contextId.occurrenceNote: The noun "breath" can be translated with the verb "breathe" or "blow." This image represents God causing the wind to blow away the clouds. Alternate translation: "God blew away the clouds so that the skies were clear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: By his breath he made the skies clear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fringes" represents a small part that we can see of something that is much bigger. Alternate translation: "See, these things that God has done show only a small part of his great power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: See, these are but the fringes of his ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Justice is spoken of as if it were an object that could be taken away or given. Taking it away represents refusing to treat Job with justice. Alternate translation: "has refused to treat me justly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: has taken away my justice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hold fast" is a metaphor that represents being determined to continue to say something. The abstract noun "righteousness" can be expressed with "righteous." Alternate translation: "I am determined to continue saying that I am righteous" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: I hold fast to my righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "will not let it go" is a metaphor that represents not stopping saying something. Alternate translation: "will not stop saying that I am righteous" or "will not stop saying so" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will not let it go

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "rises up against me" is a metaphor meaning "opposes me." The whole phrase refers to Job's adversary. Alternate translation: "him who opposes me" or "my adversary" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: him who rises up against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor meaning "kills him" or "causes him to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: cuts him off

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor meaning "kills him" or "makes him stop living" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: takes away his life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the heritage of the oppressor" is a metaphor representing what will happen to the oppressor. What God will do to him is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that God will give him. Alternate translation: "what the Almighty will do to the oppressor" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the heritage of the oppressor that he receives from the Almighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "ties up the streams" means damming or blocking the streams. Alternate translation: "He blocks the streams so they do not flow" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He ties up the streams so they do not run

contextId.occurrenceNote: In 28:12-28, wisdom and understanding are spoken of as if they were precious objects that are in some place and people want to find them. Finding wisdom and understanding represents becoming wise and learning to understand things well. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Becoming wise and understanding is spoken of as finding wisdom and understanding. Alternate translation: "How do people become wise? How do people learn to understand things well" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Where will wisdom be found? Where is the place of understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) wisdom is spoken of as if it were something that people can buy. Alternate translation: "People do not know what it is worth" or 2) the word translated as "price" means "place." Alternate translation: "People do not know where it is" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Man does not know its price

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wisdom is spoken of as if it were in a place and comes to people. Its coming represents people becoming wise. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: From where, then, comes wisdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Understanding is spoken of as if it were in a place. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Where is the place of understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wisdom is spoken of as if it were in a certain place. Alternate translation: "God knows how to find wisdom. He knows where it is" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God understands the way to it; he knows its place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes God deciding how much water should be in each place. Possible meanings are that this refers to deciding 1) how much rain should be in each cloud or 2) how much water should be in each sea. Alternate translation: "decided how much water should be in each place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: parceled out the waters by measure

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "depart from evil" means refusing to do evil things. The abstract noun "understanding" can be expressed with the verb "understand." Alternate translation: "if you refuse to do evil, then you will understand many things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to depart from evil is understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's lamp shining on Job represents God blessing Job. Alternate translation: "when God's blessing was like a lamp shining its light on my head" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when his lamp shined on my head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking through darkness represents experiencing difficult situations. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when I walked through darkness by his light

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of when he was young and strong as if his days were the time when the harvest is ripe. Alternate translation: "when I was young and strong" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in the ripeness of my days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Someone's blessing coming on another represents that person blessing another. Alternate translation: "He who was about to perish would bless me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The blessing of him who was about to perish came on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: People often spoke of righteousness as if it were clothing. Alternate translation: "I did what was righteous, and it was like clothing that I put on" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I put on righteousness, and it clothed me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents helping blind people. Alternate translation: "I was like eyes for blind people" or "I guided blind people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I was eyes to blind people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents helping blind people. Alternate translation: "I was like feet for lame people" or "I supported lame people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I was feet to lame people
