contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "I was a father" represents providing for people. Alternate translation: "I provided for needy people as a father provides for his children" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I was a father to needy people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of unrighteous people who persecute others as if they were wild animals that attack their victims by picking them up between their teeth. Alternate translation: "I made unrighteous people stop persecuting people, like someone who breaks the jaw of a wild animal and rescues its victim from between its teeth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I broke the jaws of ... I plucked the victim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "nest" represents Job's home and family. Job used to speak as if he were a bird that lived in a nest with his baby birds. Alternate translation: "I will die at home with my family" or "I will die in the safety of my home" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will die in my nest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job used to speak of his strength as if he were strong like a well-watered tree. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My roots ... my branches

contextId.occurrenceNote: A new bow is very strong. Job's bow of strength in his hand represents his physical strength. Alternate translation: "I am always strong like a new bow" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the bow of my strength is always new in my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents waiting eagerly for Job to speak in order to benefit from what said. Alternate translation: "they eagerly waited for me to speak in order to benefit from what I said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they opened their mouth wide to drink in my words

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the kindness they saw in Job's face. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the light of my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "selected their way" represents deciding what they should do. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I selected their way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their strength perishing is a metaphor that represents no longer being strong but weak. The phrase "mature age" refers to them being old. Alternate translation: "men who had become old and had no strength" or "men who had become old and weak" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: men in whom the strength of their mature age had perished

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "were the sons of fools" represents having the characteristics fools. Alternate translation: "They were like fools" or "they were fools" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They were the sons of fools

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "indeed" shows that what follows strengthens the previous thought. Here "sons of nameless people" represents having the characteristics of nameless people. Alternate translation: "indeed, they were nameless people" or "indeed, they were worthless" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: indeed, sons of nameless people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being "nameless" represents having no honor or respect. It means that they are worthless. Alternate translation: "worthless people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: nameless people

contextId.occurrenceNote: A bow that is unstrung is not useful. The phrase "has unstrung the string of my bow" is a metaphor for making Job powerless. Alternate translation: "God has taken away my power to defend myself" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God has unstrung the string to my bow

contextId.occurrenceNote: A restraint keeps a person from moving freely and doing what he wants. Here "restraint" represents refraining from doing something, and "cast off restraint" represents not refraining from doing something. In this case the mockers did not refrain from being cruel to Job. Alternate translation: "do not refrain from being cruel to me" or "do whatever cruel things they want to do to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: cast off restraint before my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks about the mockers treating him cruelly as if they were a mob and an army attacking him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Armies would pile up mounds of dirt along a city's wall in order to climb over the wall and attack the city. Job speaks of the mockers preparing to attack him as if they were doing that. Alternate translation: "prepare to attack me like an army that prepares to attack a city" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: pile up against me their siege mounds

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents keeping Job from escaping their attack. Alternate translation: "They prevent me from escaping from them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They destroy my path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "push forward disaster" represents trying to make disaster happen. Alternate translation: "they try to make disaster happen to me" or "they try to destroy me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they push forward disaster for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hold them back" represents stopping them from doing something. Alternate translation: "men who have no one to stop them from attacking me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: men who have no one to hold them back

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks about the mockers treating him cruelly as if they were an army attacking him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents many coming to attack him at once, like giant ocean waves rolling in on him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they roll themselves in on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Job has become terrified or 2) things are happening to Job that make him afraid. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Terrors are turned upon me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks as if his life were a liquid and his body were a container. He feels he is about to die. Alternate translation: "Now I am dying" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Now my life is pouring out from within me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the pain in his bones as if his bones were being pierced. Alternate translation: "my bones ache terribly" or "I have sharp pain in my bones" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my bones in me are pierced

contextId.occurrenceNote: The image of God's force seizing Job is a metaphor. Possible meanings are 1) it represents Job's pain. Alternate translation: "My pain feels like God has grabbed my clothing tightly" or 2) it represents God's causing Job's many problems. Alternate translation: "It is as though by his great force God has grabbed me by my clothes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God's great force has seized my clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The image of God's force wrapping around Job is a metaphor. Possible meanings are 1) it represents Job's pain. Alternate translation: "he wraps the collar of my tunic tightly around me" or 2) it represents God's causing Job's many problems. Alternate translation: "It is as though he grabs me by the collar of my tunic" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it wraps around me like the collar of my tunic

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job says that God has humiliated him. Alternate translation: "It is as though he has thrown me in the mud" or "He has humiliated me, like a person thrown in the mud" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He has thrown me into the mud

contextId.occurrenceNote: These expressions represent the extreme suffering that God made Job endure. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: lift me up to the wind ... throw me back and forth in a storm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bring me to death" represents causing Job to die. Alternate translation: "you will cause me to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will bring me to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the world of the dead as if it were a house to which God has appointed all living things to go. Alternate translation: "the world of the dead, to which everything that has ever lived goes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the house appointed for all the living

contextId.occurrenceNote: Looking for good represents hoping for good things, and evil coming represents evil things happening. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When I hoped for good, then evil came

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "light" represents God's blessing and favor and "darkness" represents trouble and suffering. Alternate translation: "I waited for the light of God's blessing, but instead I experienced the darkness of suffering" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I waited for light ... darkness came

contextId.occurrenceNote: Days of affliction coming on Job represents Job experiencing affliction for many days. Alternate translation: "I experience affliction many days" or "I suffer every day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: days of affliction have come on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "have gone about" represents living. Alternate translation: "I have lived" or "I live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have gone about

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "living in the dark" is a metaphor that represents being extremely sad. The phrase "but not because of the sun" clarifies that "living in the dark" is a metaphor, that is, the darkness is not caused by the sun being hidden. Alternate translation: "like one who is terribly sad" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: like one who was living in the dark, but not because of the sun

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being a brother to these animals is a metaphor for being like them. Alternate translation: "I am like jackals and ostriches that cry out in the wilderness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a brother to jackals, a companion of ostriches

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of making a promise about what he would look at as though his eyes were a person and he made a covenant with them. Alternate translation: "I have made a firm promise about what I will look at" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: I have made a covenant with my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God's response to people's behavior as if it were the portion of an inheritance that God gives. Alternate translation: "For how will God above respond to me? What will the Almighty on high do?" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For what is the portion from God above, the inheritance from the Almighty on high?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my ways" and "my steps" are metaphors for Job's behavior. Here "see my ways" and "count all my steps" are metaphors for knowing everything Job does. Job uses this question to emphasize that God does know all he does. Alternate translation: "Certainly God watches me and knows everything that I do." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Does not God see my ways and count all my steps?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "walked" and "hurried" are metaphors that represent how Job lived. Alternate translation: "done anything false or purposely deceived anyone" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walked with falsehood, if my foot has hurried to deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: People used balances to weigh items and to determine their value. This image represents judging honestly. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "let me be judged honestly" or "let God judge me honestly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: let me be weighed in an even balance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my step" is a metaphor for Job's behavior, and "turned out of the right way" is a metaphor for changing from living right. Alternate translation: "If I have changed from living right" or "If I have stopped doing what is right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: If my step has turned aside from the way

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor for being guilty. Alternate translation: "if I am guilty of any sin at all" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if any spot has stuck to my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the harm that sleeping with another woman causes as if it were a fire that destroys everything. The words "that" and "it" refer to sleeping with another man's wife. Alternate translation: "For adultery is like a fire that burns up everything from here to Abaddon and that would burn up all my harvest" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For that is a fire that consumes as far as Abaddon, and it would burn all my harvest to the root

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are probably a metaphor for "destroys everything so I have nothing good for the rest of my life," but you should probably translate this literally. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: consumes as far as Abaddon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "saw" is a metaphor for "knew," "support" is a metaphor for "approval," and "the city gate" is a metonym for the leaders who sit at the city gate. Alternate translation: "I knew that the leaders at the city gate would approve of me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I saw my support in the city gate

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "have hidden my sins" represents trying to keep people from knowing that he had sinned. Alternate translation: "If ... I have tried to keep my sins a secret" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: If ... I have hidden my sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents trying to keep people from knowing that he is guilty. Alternate translation: "by hiding the evidence of my guilt inside my tunic" or "like one who hides the evidence of his guilt inside his tunic" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: by hiding my guilt inside my tunic

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my signature" represents Job's promise that everything he is saying is true. He speaks of his complaint as if he had written a legal document. Alternate translation: "I solemnly promise that all I have said is true" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: here is my signature

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents putting it where everyone could read it. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Surely I would carry it openly on my shoulder; I would put it on like a crown

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my steps" represents Job's actions. Alternate translation: "I would declare to him an accounting for all I have done" or "I would tell him everything I have done" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I would declare to him an accounting for my steps

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: "he considered himself righteous" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he was righteous in his own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares Elihu's anger to someone starting a fire. Also, this can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Then Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry with Job" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Then was kindled the anger of Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram; it was kindled against Job

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares Elihu's anger to someone starting a fire. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Elihu also became very angry with his three friends" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Elihu's anger was also kindled against his three friends

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the men were done speaking to Job. This speaks of the men possibly having an answer as if the answer were an object that would be in their mouths. Alternate translation: "that these three men had nothing else to say" or "that these three men had no more answers to give Job" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: that there was no answer in the mouths of these three men

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares Elihu's anger to someone starting a fire. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "he became very angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: his anger was kindled

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of God responding to Job and correcting him as if he were defeating him in battle. Alternate translation: "to refute Job" or "to answer Job" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to defeat Job

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of having a lot to say as being full of words. Alternate translation: "I have so much to say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am full of words

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Job preparing what he will say as if he were setting up and organizing physical objects. Alternate translation: "prepare what you will say, and stand up and answer me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: set your words in order before me and stand up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "I am just as you are in God's judgment" or "God judges me the same way that he judges you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am just as you are in God's sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Though people are not made out of clay, God has made everyone as a potter carefully makes things out of clay. Alternate translation: "God has made both of us just as a potter forms things from clay" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I also have been formed out of the clay

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he will not hinder Job or burden him. He speaks of emotional burden here as if it were a heavy physical burden. Alternate translation: "neither will I burden you" or "I will not oppress you with what I say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: neither will my pressure be heavy upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if the person were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Stocks" are wooden blocks a jailer puts around a prisoner's feet to restrict his movement. Job speaks of feeling like he is a prisoner by saying that he is in stocks. Alternate translation: "I feel he has made me a prisoner" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He puts my feet in stocks

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of people being in a deep sleep as if the sleep fell upon them or overcame them. Alternate translation: "when people are fully asleep on their bed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when deep sleep falls upon men, in slumber on the bed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of God making people aware of things as if he were opening their ears so that they could hear. Alternate translation: "then God reveals things to people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: then God opens the ears of men

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of God keeping someone from doing something as if he were physically pulling him away from harm. Alternate translation: "in order to keep him from" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in order to pull man back from

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as "the pit." Alternate translation: "the place where dead people are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as "the pit." Alternate translation: "the place where dead people are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as "the pit." Alternate translation: "the place where dead people are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the man's flesh again being as strong as it was when he was young. Alternate translation: "it will become strong again, as it was when he was young" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it is restored to the days of his youth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as "the pit." Alternate translation: "the place where dead people are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of saving the man from dying as if he had died and was being brought back to life. Alternate translation: "to keep him from dying and going to the pit" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to bring his soul back from the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as "the pit." Alternate translation: "the place where dead people are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Job's sickness and suffering is spoken of as if it were a "wound." Alternate translation: "I am sick and no one can heal me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My wound is incurable

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "walk" is an idiom for how a person acts. Alternate translation: "who behaves like wicked men" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who walks with wicked men

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he gives to a person what he deserves for the work he has done. Here "work" is a metaphor for what a person does. Alternate translation: "For he gives to a person what he deserves in return for he does" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For he pays back a person's work

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two questions speak of God not punishing wicked people as if he were being silent and hiding his face. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When he stays silent, who can condemn him? If he hides his face, who can perceive him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares a godless ruler harming people as if he were a hunter trapping his prey. Alternate translation: "no one to harm the people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: no one to entrap people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of "words" as if they were objects, and of speaking many words as if it were piling those objects one on top of the other. Alternate translation: "he speaks many words against God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he piles up words against God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of "transgressions" as if they were objects, and of committing many transgressions as if it were piling those objects one on top of the other. He asks this question to emphasize that Job does nothing to God by his transgressions. Alternate translation: "If you committed a great many transgressions, you still do nothing to him." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: If your transgressions pile up high, what do you do to him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of God enabling people to have hope in troubling circumstances as if he were giving to them songs which they can sing during the night. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who gives songs in the night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of "words" as if they were objects, and of speaking many words as if it were piling those objects one on top of the other. The word "knowledge" can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: "he speaks many words without knowing what he is talking about" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: he piles up words without knowledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of explaining things to Job as if he were going to show those things to Job. Alternate translation: "I will explain some things to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will show you some things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of having knowledge of many different subjects as if it were getting his knowledge from far away places. Alternate translation: "I will show you my great knowledge" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will obtain my knowledge from far off

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "someone" refers to Elihu himself. He speaks of being very knowledgeable as if it were being mature in knowledge. Alternate translation: "I, who am with you, am very knowledgeable" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: someone who is mature in knowledge is with you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of God protecting righteous people as if God were watching them with his eyes, and of God ceasing to protect them as if he withdrew his eyes from them. Alternate translation: "He does not stop protecting the righteous people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He does not withdraw his eyes from righteous people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of God honoring the righteous people as if God were causing them to sit on thrones like kings do. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: sets them on thrones like kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of God honoring the righteous people as if he lifted them up to a high place. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "he lifts them up" or "he honors them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: they are lifted up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of a person being made to suffer as if that person were trapped in ropes that cause suffering. Alternate translation: "someone causes them to suffer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: trapped in cords of suffering

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of causing a person to listen as if it were opening that person's ear. Alternate translation: "He also causes them to listen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He also opens their ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of stopping an action as if it were turning back from it. Alternate translation: "to stop committing iniquity" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to turn back from iniquity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of a person dying violently as if someone had killed them with a sword. Alternate translation: "they will die a violent death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they will perish by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of a person remaining angry as if that person stored up their anger like one would store up treasure. Alternate translation: "are always angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: store up their anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of God disciplining people as if God were tying them up with ropes. Alternate translation: "even when God punishes them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: even when God ties them up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of God causing a person to listen as if God were opening their ears. See how you translated this in [Job 36:10](../36/10.md). Alternate translation: "he causes them to listen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he opens their ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of living without trouble as if it were being in a wide-open space where there were no hardships. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: into a broad place where there is no hardship

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of living prosperously as if it were having one's table filled with the best foods. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: where your table would be set with food full of fatness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) that "peoples" refers to people in general and "cut off in their place" is a metaphor for oppressing others by dragging them away from their homes. Alternate translation: "when people drag others away from their homes" or 2) that "peoples" represents nations and "cut off in their place" is a metaphor for nations being destroyed. Alternate translation: "when nations will perish" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when peoples are cut off in their place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of people not being fully able to understand God's deeds as if people were only able to see those deeds from far away. Alternate translation: "they do not fully understand them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they see those deeds only from far away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of the sky as if it were a "hut" in which God lives. Alternate translation: "from the sky, where God lives" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: from his hut

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of the deep parts of the sea as if the sea were a plant and its depths were its roots. Possible meanings are 1) although the lightning causes light in the sky, the deep parts of the sea remain dark. Alternate translation: "but the depths of the sea remain dark" or 2) the lightning in the sky cause even the depths of the sea to have light. Alternate translation: "and lights up the depths of the sea" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: and covers the roots of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of the lightning that storms cause as if God were holding the lightning in his hand and directing it to strike where he wills. Possible meanings are 1) that God holds the lightning bolts in his hands in order to throw them, or 2) that God hides the lightning bolts in his hands until he is ready to use them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He fills his hands with the lightning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of his heart beating violently as if it were to jump out of his chest. Alternate translation: "it moves out of its place" or "it beats violently" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: it is moved out of its place

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Elihu speaks of the thunder as if it is God's voice. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the noise of his voice, the sound that goes out from his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of the farthest places on the earth as if they were the earth's borders. Alternate translation: "everywhere in the world" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to the edges of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu continues to speak of the thunder as if it is God's voice. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: A voice roars after it ... the voice of his majesty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of the storm blowing in from the south as if the storm has a place where it resides until it comes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The storm comes from its chamber in the south

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of the cold north wind as if it were God's breath. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "God's breath makes ice" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: By the breath of God ice is given

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of God causing the storm clouds to be full of water as if the moisture weighed heavily on the clouds. Alternate translation: "he causes the thick clouds to be full of moisture" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he weighs down the thick cloud with moisture

contextId.occurrenceNote: In biblical days, mirrors were made of metal. Elihu speaks of the sky giving no rain as if it were as hard as solid metal. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: as strong as a mirror of cast metal

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of the inability to understand as if it were having darkness in one's mind. Alternate translation: "because we do not understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: because of the darkness of our minds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of a person being destroyed as if the person were swallowed up. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "for God to destroy him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: to be swallowed up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "fearsome" means that it causes fear. Elihu speaks of God's majesty as if it were something that rests upon God. Alternate translation: "God's majesty causes people to fear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: over God is fearsome majesty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "we cannot approach him" or 2) this is a metaphor in which Elihu speaks of a person's being unable to fully understand God as if he could not find God. Alternate translation: "we cannot comprehend him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: we cannot find him

contextId.occurrenceNote: "obscures my plans" or "confuses my purposes." How Job confuses God's plans is spoken of as if he were making God's plans harder to see. The abstract noun "darkness" can be translated as the verb "darkens." Alternate translation: "darkens plans" or "makes plans hard to see" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: brings darkness to plans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes creating the earth as though he was building a structure. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I laid the earth's foundations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the way that he prevented the sea from covering all of the earth to holding it back with doors. Alternate translation: "prevented the water from flooding over the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: shut up the sea with doors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the way that he made a boundary for the sea to containing the sea with bars and doors. Alternate translation: "I set up its barriers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I placed its bars and doors

contextId.occurrenceNote: The light of dawn is spoken of as if it seizes the horizons of the earth. Alternate translation: "grasp the ends of the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: take hold of the edges of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The daylight is pictured as causing wicked people to leave like shaking something to remove unwanted things. Alternate translation: "shake wicked people out of the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: shake the wicked out of it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The raised arm of the wicked represents their power and intention to do evil things, but the wicked stop doing those evil things when the morning light comes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their uplifted arm is broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Death is spoken of as if it were a city that had gates through which people enter into it. This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: "Has anyone shown the gates of death to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Have the gates of death been revealed to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Snow and hail are pictured as being stored by Yahweh to do his will. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: storehouses for the snow ... storehouses for the hail

contextId.occurrenceNote: Becoming the father of the dew is a metaphor for creating it. Alternate translation: "causes the drops of dew to exist" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: fathers the drops of dew

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are skins that people sew together so that they can hold water. Yahweh refers to the thick clouds as "waters skins" because they hold much water just like water skins. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the water skins

contextId.occurrenceNote: The horse runs over the ground so quickly that the ground passes by like water that a person drinks. Alternate translation: "runs very fast over the ground" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: swallows up ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns "glory," "dignity," "honor," and "majesty" are spoken of as if they were clothing that a person could put on. They can be translated as adjectives and verbs. Alternate translation: "make yourself glorious; do something great so people will respect you and honor you; make people think you are a great king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: clothe yourself in glory and dignity; array yourself in honor and majesty

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract noun "anger" is spoken of as it it were something that usually could be held in a container, but in this situation there is so much of it that what does not fit needs to be spread around. It is also a metonym for the actions a person takes when he is angry. You may need to make explicit why the person is angry. Alternate translation: "Be angry because people are proud, and punish them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Scatter around the excess of your anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "armor" is a metaphor for the hard scales or hide on his back. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "No one can penetrate his very thick hide." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Who can penetrate his double armor?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "shields" is a metaphor for Leviathan's hide. Both shields and Leviathan's hide protect well and deflect arrows and other weapons. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: shields

contextId.occurrenceNote: Chaff cannot hurt Leviathan, and sling stones are just as ineffective as chaff. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to him sling stones become chaff

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents understanding. Alternate translation: "but now I really understand you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but now my eye sees you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Fire is a metaphor for anger, and starting a fire is a metaphor for becoming angry. Alternate translation: "I have become very angry with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My wrath is kindled against you
